title: How to Set CSS Grid Named Areas
description:
In this week's live video, we'll be covering using grid-template-areas to set up your grid in a semantic way. This will allow you to attach content to a grid space without specifying line numbers. title: Getting started with Pseudo Elements (::before and ::after)
description:
Unlike its cousin the pseudo class, a pseudo element is generated in the browser by your CSS. The two most powerful (and ubiquitous) are ::before and ::after.

title: Using a CSS ::after element to create interesting borders
description:
Blog Post: https://bryanlrobinson.com/blog/2018/08/07/top-3-uses-of-after-and-before-css-pseudo-elements/

Until the Houdini Paint API hits all browsers, you may feel stuck with very boring borders for your elements. Using simple CSS and ::before and ::after, you can bring some interesting ideas to all browsers.

In this tutorial, I'll show you how to make a truncated, full-gradient, skewed border for any headline or text.

title: How to create a simple CSS image overlay with ::before or ::after
description:
Practical CSS Grid - Learn about this revolution in Web design with my 2 hour course: https://store.codecontemporary.com/practical-css-grid

See the blog post here: https://bryanlrobinson.com/blog/2018/04/30/how-to-css-after-elements-for-background-overlays/
The CSS ::after and ::before pseudo-elements have many great tricks. The easiest and best of which is introducing an overlay on an image with no additional HTML. This allows us to introduce gradients, blend modes and all sorts of fancy web design techniques to our images in a cross-browser way.

In this video, I walk you through adding this functionality to your code.


More and more in web design, we find ourselves putting text on top of images. More often than not, this is a dangerous game. Images have dynamic color and lighting and text for the most part is one color. This is often a nightmare for readability and accessibility.

Enter the CSS ::after pseudo-element and some simple tricks to add an overlay to any image. 

In this tutorial, we'll put together a simple overlay and then spice it up with some CSS Gradients
